title: Between 9 May 2018 and 29 June 2018, how many Cabinet-level officials in the Trump Administration will cease to hold a cabinet-level position?
preds: The only question I have is about Mulvaney, who has two jobs right now, but it appears that his current subordinate will be the new leader of the CFPB.
Just going all in on zero because there is only two days left.
i was way off consensus and was influenced by other forecasters.
NOW SEC. OF DHS IS LOOKING GOOD AS A SACRIFICIAL LAMB. DT is almost ready to derail the press again but he needs to feed the squirrels to do so.
Shifting a few points toward no due because there's only a week or so left.
DHS and EPA are looking like candidates.
Main uncertainty is Scott Pruitt and whether he will be out within this timeframe.

Sen. Jim Inhof ( a questionable paragon of Ethical Fortitude himself) and Mentor to EPA Director Scott Pruitt has publicly called for a sit down with him. Imhofe is probably going to tell him his future, but Scott will weasel as long as he can. He is gone, just a question of when, right now hes pulling ethanol supports off the table to lower food prices but Corn back in the commodity market as a food instead of as energy. I'd fire him after the Farmers are through calling for his head or mine.
Pruitt becoming more of a problem but there's just a couple of weeks to go https://www.politico.com/story/2018/06/13/laura-ingraham-fire-pruitt-623446
Pruitt of the EPA is headed home - just a question of before or after the 4th of July.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/epa-chief-scott-pruitt-tapped-aide-donors-to-help-wife-land-job-at-conservative-group/2018/06/13/f54c87fa-6db1-11e8-afd5-778aca903bbe_story.html?utm_term=.903e08ad48c8 How many times does this have to happen for him to get fired? Adjusting +5 for 1
Updating the calculation in my last comment[1], Trump has averaged one cabinet-level official per 102 days. Seventeen days remain in the challenge. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/733580
Doesn't seem like big mouth Kudlow's 'mild' heart attack will be contagious. Seems these oldies are getting stressed out defending the indefensible though.
Time passing plus will be all bubbly about North Korea summit for awhile.

Logical president: Don't fire anyone before the summit, as you don't need the headache and distraction from your achievement. Trump: I like fire. Still, I think people are fairly safe so long as he's pursuing the summit and self-pardons.
I think Sessions will be fired.

The mundanely corrupt ones seem safe, and indeed admired by their boss.  The most ambiguous case is the Attorney-General.  At the moment The Leader Of The Free World seems to be heeding the warnings against sacking him being bleated by the terrified Republican leadership (this is a technical term, not meant to imply that any of them are either real Republicans or real leaders).   However, do stay tuned--he has a longish record of being unable to overcome his reality-show impulses.  ("Reality" is also a technical term, not meant to imply that any shows with that label reflect reality; nearest analog is perhaps "Democratic People's Republic of Korea.")

https://politi.co/2xmBsLL "Investor Wilbur Ross . . .  the commerce secretary has been increasingly marginalized, with his agency widely seen in the White House as a mess. “Trump himself has lashed out at Ross in Oval Office meetings, telling the man who once helped bail him out in Atlantic City that he’s ‘past his prime’ and ‘no longer a killer’ and trying to bench him from making trade deals, according to three people familiar with the comments. Despite being one of the administration’s leading protectionist voices early on, Ross was initially left off a May trade delegation to China led by Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin. “But now Ross is heading back to China in early June in hope of cutting some type of trade deal that delivers on Trump’s campaign promises to extract concessions from Beijing on behalf of American workers.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  So, the Commerce Secretary is on thin ice, too!

WoC0.41 on 0 based on 81 count from 48 of us.  Out of the 15 only 2 or 3 would really be on the shortlist. Maybe one will just get sick of the chaos and in-coherency.  Maybe one (Pruitt) of the 7 will go. The EPA freeloading king would work in a granite quarry to pay back debts if there was a skerrick of integrity. Just boggles my mind that one can be so blatantly corrupt and treat the public purse like it's free money going out of fashion in some African King film audition.  Maybe one of the billionaires (real ones like DeVos and Ross) will get bored and want to return to biz. Or go through the revolving door to private sector for big bucks.
With the North Korea Summit off the table in the near term, I do not foresee any more than two adjustments to his roster.
Not sure Pruitt's drama has reached fever-pitch yet. And it's been quiet on the Kelly front as of late.
Not inconceivable that the SH COS and Sec Def would go together if they felt the situation required it.
Kelley Ann tweeted that she expects some more churn this summer. Good enough for me. (ok, I'm just baiting those that love to loathe her- I'll be better after this primary on the 22d)

In his first 14 months, Trump averaged one cabinet member lost every 108 days.[1] To fully count cabinet-level turnover, one needs to add the Director of the CIA (not a confirmed cabinet member, but a cabinet-level official), bringing the average as of today to one every 96 days. The challenge runs 51 days, of which 46 remain. @Anneinak had a good find that Kirstjen Nielsen is potentially close to resigning.  1. https://www.npr.org/2018/03/19/594164065/trump-cabinet-turnover-sets-record-going-back-100-years

Always had close to hand from day one a resignation letter printed undated ready to be signed, it's a wonder Neilsen didn't have one too. It's a wonder they all don't have it on hand in this chaotic unprincipled admin.  Once you threaten it, your standing goes down - so maybe it'll happen for real next.  Friday 29th June is a short timeline though.
Statistically, one is likely - but DT likes to adjust his board to attack major issues, so ill be watching for change of mission corrections before I go big on 3.

Some Dart throwing math - as of 5-12-18 - Trump in office 477 days with 4 Cabinet members gone. That's a daily rate of .0084. This question covers 51 days = extrapolates to .43% of a person (that's less than half a person) could leave or be fired. 
Agree with @Anneinak and @Daveinsea naming the possibilities that loom. I would add the possibility of Kelly. 
Given the timeline.. ?

Thoughts about forecasting for "0":
-It is the status quo and the status quo is always more likely, unless there is clear evidence of something about to happen.
-This question will be open for about 50 days.  If it resolves as "0",  and one wanted to arrive at that forecast about a week early, that would mean increasing the "0" forecast by about 2% per day. Thoughts about forecasting for 3 or 4:
This would be the result of a "normal" resignation or firing, PLUS a "Saturday Night Massacre" type of event, which I perceive to be a greater possibility in this presidency than in any past for a long, long time. "One" could be anybody.

"Two" would be less likely than "one", except it could also be a "Saturday Night Massacre".
DHS head on block for uptick in Illegal Crossings. She has her resignation letter prepared.

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/10/us/politics/trump-homeland-security-secretary-resign.html?emc=edit_th_180511&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=778250250511 Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, told colleagues she was close to resigning after President Trump berated her on Wednesday in front of the entire cabinet for what he said was her failure to adequately secure the nation’s borders, according to several current and former officials familiar with the episode. Ms. Nielsen, who is a protégée of John F. Kelly, the White House chief of staff, has drafted a resignation letter but has not submitted it, according to two of the people. As the head of the Department of Homeland Security,. . . .
. . . 
Tyler Q. Houlton, a spokesman for the Department of Homeland Security, disputed that Ms. Nielsen had drafted a resignation letter and was close to resigning, calling those assertions “false.” Mr. Trump’s anger about immigration has grown in recent weeks, according to several officials. He repeatedly claimed credit for the fact that during his first year in office, illegal border crossings dropped to their lowest levels in decades. But this year, they have risen again, robbing him of one of his favorite talking points. In remarks to reporters before Wednesday’s meeting, Mr. Trump hinted at the anger that would cause him to erupt once TV cameras were led out of the room. “We’ve very much toughened up the border, but the laws are horrible,” Mr. Trump said. “The laws in this country for immigration and illegal immigration are absolutely horrible. And we have to do something about it — not only the wall, which we’re building sections of wall right now.”
. . . 
During the meeting, Mr. Trump yelled about the United States’ porous border and said more needed to be done to fix it. When members of his cabinet pointed out that the country relies on day laborers who cross the border each day, Mr. Trump said that was fine, but continued to complain, one person said. The president also complained about the continued failure of his administration to find a way to build a wall along the southern border with Mexico, two people familiar with the episode said. Ms. Nielsen viewed the president’s rant as directed mostly at her, and she told associates after the meeting that she should not continue in the job if he did not view her as effective. One person close to Ms. Nielsen said she was miserable in her job. Mr. Trump has clashed with Ms. Nielsen for weeks about his belief that more should be done to secure the border. In early April, the president repeatedly expressed frustration with Ms. Nielsen that her department was not doing enough to close loopholes that were allowing illegal immigrants into the country, according to one official familiar with those discussions. During those discussions, officials had presented Mr. Trump with a list of proposals that would help border agents crack down on those trying to cross the border illegally and send them back more quickly. The president urged Ms. Nielsen to be more aggressive, the official said. One persistent issue has been Mr. Trump’s belief that Ms. Nielsen and other officials in the department were resisting his direction that parents be separated from their children when families cross illegally into the United States, several officials said. The president and his aides in the White House had been pushing a family separation policy for weeks as a way of deterring families from trying to cross the border illegally.
. . . 
The episode at the cabinet meeting on Wednesday is the latest evidence of staff turmoil at the White House, where many of Mr. Trump’s top advisers have either been fired or have resigned in recent weeks. The president fired Rex W. Tillerson, his secretary of state, and pushed out Lt. Gen. H. R. McMaster, his second national security adviser, replacing him with John R. Bolton, who in turn fired several top aides at the National Security Council. Those staff changes followed the announced departures of Gary D. Cohn, the president’s top economic adviser in the White House, and Hope Hicks, who was Mr. Trump’s communications director and confidante. Thomas P. Bossert, the president’s homeland security adviser, also quit. Mr. Trump’s relationship with Mr. Kelly, who was the president’s first secretary of homeland security, has also soured in recent months as the president has grown weary of Mr. Kelly’s attempts to impose order on his White House operations. Ms. Nielsen was Mr. Kelly’s chief of staff at the Homeland Security Department, and followed Mr. Kelly to the White House when he became chief of staff. She frequently clashed with other members of the president’s staff as she and Mr. Kelly sought to end the chaotic access to Mr. Trump in the Oval Office. Mr. Trump later nominated Ms. Nielsen to be the new homeland security secretary on Mr. Kelly’s recommendation. Even so, people close to Mr. Trump said he viewed her with suspicion because she had spent years working for President George W. Bush as a homeland security aide and later as a top official for the Transportation Security Administration in the Homeland Security Department.
I started with a base rate of 0.3 cabinet level official per month and I eyeballed the rest
While turnover in the trump administration is a given and there are always people under threat, I am going very low given the tight time frame of the question.

The big bloodbath is probably over.  The Leader Of The Free World now seems to have just about the lineup of twits and toadies he wants.  However, one must always be alert to the possibility that one or two will inadvertently stumble onto the paths of righteousness and have to be sacked.  General Mattis is probably safe, since the Prez is afraid of him, but Ambassador Haley is sometimes insufficiently fawning and of course General Sessions is perennially at risk.  Tough call, but staying fairly low on account of the relatively short time frame.
Haruspication.  That's the way to go on these questions.
Kelly & Pruitt soon and if Mulluer probe make more revelations then more than 2

Here's my off-the-top-of-my-head list of folks who seem to be in trouble or not getting along well with DJT:
Kelley, Pruitt, Mattis, Carson, Sessions and Haley, also possibly Lightzinger.
The question will be open for only 7 weeks, so that reduces the number.  
I will adjust this after calculating the base rate in this administration.
EPA Admin and WH COS would be the two I think could go. Maybe Nikki Haley if she irks Trump enough. But given the relatively short time frame, I think it's most likely that no one departs.
